sentences.sentence: By Vijay Jog and Jack MintzIn its fall economic statement, Ottawa announced it would explore removing the rule that restricts Canadian pension funds to holding no more than 30 per cent of the voting shares of most corporations.

The proposal has already provoked a negative reaction from pension plans, who would like to see the cap removed for all assets, not just Canadian.On this point, we agree with the pension plan managers.

Giving Canadian assets this special tax lustre amounts to political interference in pension fund portfolio decisions, which could lead to suboptimal returns less likely to cover the funds' obligations.
In 2005, Canada eliminated the foreign property rule that blocked pension funds from accessing foreign assets at all.

We don't need a backhanded undermining of the obvious benefits from pension diversification across both domestic and foreign assets.As we have long argued, however, removing the 30 per cent rule even for Canadian corporations would distort capital markets and cause substantial revenue losses for governments.

The problem is that pension plans will become active managers of, rather than passive investors in, Canadian operating companies - not because of superior management skill but because they are tax-exempt.It's true that pension funds provide "patient capital."
Their passive investments may also result in a lower cost of capital for firms they invest in.
But pension plans are not like other investors: they are tax-exempt.

In making acquisitions in private markets (or acquiring public companies that become private), they can lend internal debt to the operating taxable company, which can write off the resulting interest to eliminate corporate tax payments, which also isn't taxed when it is paid back to the (tax-exempt) pension funds to which it is owed.

Or the pension plan can create a trust or partnership whose distribution of corporate profits to the fund is tax-exempt.These tax advantages enable pension plans interested in a merger or acquisition to outbid taxable companies, which do not have access to this form of tax arbitrage.

The 30 per cent rule has never applied to real estate assets, and they are now dominated by pension plan management (as well as by REITs - real estate investment trusts - that have access to similar tax arbitrage opportunities).In a tax-neutral world, ownership is determined by management excellence or synergies among merged companies that increase profits.
The target company goes to the highest bid der without being influenced by taxation.

Like all other organizations, pension funds should win bids to operate companies they'd like to control based on their management skills, not their tax-exempt status.And there's a further misallocation: once a company is no longer paying tax on its operations, it has a competitive advantage - a completely artificial one - against companies that are taxable who are trying to compete with it in whatever line of business it's in.

If you have the privilege of not paying tax, it's no surprise you'll do well against competitors that do.Our other major concern is that removing the 30 per cent rule would cost governments substantial revenues.
From 2011 to 2022, pension assets (including CPP and QPP's) grew by 80 per cent, reaching $2.9 trillion.
Non-publicly traded assets - private equity and bonds, real estate and infrastructure - now account for 35 per cent of this total.

With no limits on tax arbitrage by tax-exempt companies, federal and provincial governments could lose $3.5 billion in tax revenues for each trillion dollars in assets held by pension funds.If the 30 per cent rule were eliminated, the federal and provincial governments would need to find other ways to limit tax arbitrage by pension plans.
They could impose the new interest limitation rule for private companies on subsidiaries controlled by pension plans.
Net interest expense in excess of 30 per cent of earnings before the deduction of depreciation, interest and taxes would not be deductible.

That would help but wouldn't prevent pension plans from exploiting trust arrangements with the companies they operate.Another option would be to tax the earnings of controlled subsidiaries held by pension plans and other tax-exempt entities (e.g., charities such as university endowment funds).

This approach, similar to the U.S. "unrelated business income tax" (UBIT), can result in pension plans paying corporate tax on controlled corporate earnings.Harvard and the high economic cost of potholes(https://financialpost.com/opinion/harvard-high-economic-cost-potholes)Overly optimistic Liberals are lowballing government debt risk(https://financialpost.com/opinion/overly-optimistic-liberals-lowballing-government-debt-risk)It's time for the abdication of King Trudeau II(https://financialpost.com/opinion/time-abdication-king-trudeau-ii)On balance, though, we're not convinced removing the 30 per cent rule would create benefits big enough to offset the costs of all this new complexity.
To help support the retirement of our aging population, pension and other retirement funds should certainly continue to be tax-exempt.

But once tax-exempt status is awarded to some investors and not others, boundaries like the 30 per cent rule need to be imposed in order to minimize the resulting economic distortions and tax erosion.

Allowing pension plans to use their tax exemption to take over corporate Canada would be a step way too far.Vijay Jog is Chancellor Professor Emeritus, Carleton University, and Jack Mintz is President's Fellow, School of Public Policy, University of Calgary.Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know - add financialpost.com(https://financialpost.com/ ) to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here(https://financialpost.com/newsletters/ ).
